CONFIG.general_instructions: This project is an AI assistant for a given lesson. The output of each request must be response that guides an student in understanding a topic.  \n
CONFIG.description:
The Data and AI Intensive Research with Rigor and Reproducibility (DAIR³) program is funded by Award 5R25GM151182 of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, one of the 27 institutes of the National Institutes of Health of the United States. The principal investigators are Jing Liu (University of Michigan) and Juan B. Gutiérrez (University of Texas at San Antonio). 
The rigor of scientific research and the reproducibility of research results are essential for the validity of research findings and the trustworthiness of science. However, research rigor and reproducibility remains a significant challenge across scientific fields, especially for research with complex data types from heterogeneous sources, and long data manipulation pipelines. This is especially critical as data science and artificial intelligence (AI) methods emerge at lightning speed and researchers scramble to seize the opportunities that the new methods bring.  

While researchers recognize the importance of rigor and reproducibility, they often lack the resources and the technical know-how to achieve this consistently in practice. With funding from the National Institutes of Health, a multi-university team offers a nationwide program to equip faculty and technical staff in biomedical sciences with the skills needed to improve the rigor and reproducibility of their research, and help them transfer such skills to their trainees. 

Trainees will then be guided over a one-year period to incorporate the newly acquired mindset, skills and tools into their research; and develop training for their own institutions.  

The DAIR3 team and instructors include faculty and staff research leaders from the University of Michigan, the College of William and Mary, Jackson State University, and University of Texas San Antonio. This highly diverse team will model the culture of diversity that we promote, and will support trainees who are demographically, professionally and scientifically diverse, and are from a diverse range of institutions, including those with limited resources.

knowledgeBase.file: C:\temp\Units\UNIT_2A - Data Management - Brenda, Clifton, Yalanda\The Jackson Heart Study DAIR3 Presentation 2025.pdf
knowledgeBase.summary: Jackson State University Principal Investigators: Dr. Clifton Addison, Dr. Brenda Jenkins, Dr. Yalanda Barner The Jackson Heart Study   Jackson Medical Mall   Jackson, Mississippi  2025 2.1 Data Management Course Presented by: Dr. Clifton Addison &Dr. Brenda Jenkins The Jackson Heart Study   Jackson Medical Mall   Jackson, Mississippi  2.1 Data Management Topic 1 --Introduction to the Jackson Heart  Study  Objectives 1.Describe the JHS Study Design – Explain the purpose, population, and  structure of the JHS, including its major exams and ancillary studies. Explain Data Access Procedures –Describe the process for  requesting and obtaining JHS data, including data use agreements and  ethical considerations.Jackson Heart Study, Jackson Medical Mall https://youtu.be/X4AeQG7L8e0 Topic 1 --Introduction to the Jackson Heart Study JACKSON HEART STUDY -Jackson Medical MallBackground African Americans share a disproportionate burden of deleterious health outcomes  The Jackson Heart Study was initiated in 2000 to explore potential mechanisms and  mediators of health outcomes  JHS conducts a variety of community education and outreach activities to promote  healthy lifestyles to reduce disease risk burden  Student training programs to promote and support public health research.A Look at the Jackson Heart Study •The JHS is a single -site observational study that began in 1998 with the aims of: •Identifying genetic and environmental risk factors associated with the  disproportionate burden of cardiovascular disease in African American adults; •Conducting community education and outreach activities to promote healthy lifestyles and reduce disease risk burden; and •Conducting undergraduate and graduate level research training programs and high school science and math enrichment programs to prepare and encourage underrepresented students to pursue biomedical careers. The Jackson Heart Study Population •5306 African Americans participants were recruited from Jackson, MS  metropolitan area (Hinds, Madison, and Rankin counties) ​ The Jackson Heart Study Exam Periods •5306 African Americans participants were recruited from Jackson, MS  metropolitan area (Hinds, Madison, and Rankin counties) ​ •Exam 1 •2000 to 2004 •Exam 2 •2005 to 2008 •Exam 3 •2009- 2013 •Exam 4 ( currently ongoing)JHS Data Collection Cohorts by Periods •Exam Center visits (consents, collection of specimens, questionnaires,  clinic procedures) •Visit 1:  2000 –2004 (n=5306, 42 months) •Visit 2:  2005 –2008 (n=4203, 38 months) •Visit 3:  2009 –2013 (n=3819, 47 months) •Visit 4:  2020 –current JHS Data Collection •Annual contacts to assess changes in health status •Participants/proxies are contacted annually (AFU) by phone   •Ongoing surveillance for CVD and mortality •Hospitalizations for CVD (CHD, heart failure, stroke) •Medical records of hospitalizations for CVD are abstracted for  adjudication •Vital records and National Death IndexTypes of Data Collected in the JHS •Data collection at the baseline exam included a medical history,  physical examination, blood/urine analytes and interview questions  on areas such as:  •physical activity; stress, coping and spirituality; racism and  discrimination; socioeconomic status; and health care access.Types of Data Collected in the JHS •Phenotype -psychosocial, sleep, medical history, sociodemographic, etc. Describe the variables chosen and their rationale.Topic 2: The Process of Manuscript Development in the Jackson Heart  Study Objective: Explain Data Access Procedures – Describe the process for requesting and obtaining  JHS data, including data use agreements and ethical considerations. The role of the P&P subcommittee is: •To ensure that abstracts, presentations, and publications based on JHS are accurate and objective, and do not compromise the scientific integrity of the study; •To ensure that all investigators, particularly those who are from underrepresented racial/ethnic groups and those who are early career, participate in JHS papers; •To establish procedures that allow for timely review of JHS publications and presentations; •To prevent overlap of published material, approved proposals, and duplication of analyses; •To stimulate scientific presentations and papers from investigators.How to Access JHS Data •Manuscript proposal •Ancillary Study proposal Data Access •Data Request Form Analytic Data •JHS Website:  https://www.jacksonheartstudy.org/ Data Access:   •https://www.jacksonheartstudy.org/Research/Study -Data/Data -AccessJackson Heart Study Publications & Data Use •JHS Data Access  •Directly from JHS for approved proposals • Data from Coordinating Center  •• Specimens from Central Lab •NIH BioLINCC (Biologic Specimen and Data Repository Information Coordinating  Center) •• JHS Phenotype datasets (non- omics) • 3. Reviewer:  S. Rich   Manuscript  Proposal  (P1 xxx ) and  Title:  “xxxxxx Epi xxxxx etic  associations  forxxxxxxx ologic  and  ixxxxx  traits   in the Jackson Heart Study”     # Review  Criteria  Yes  No Needs   Revision  Not   Applicable   1 Clear  statement  of nature  of problem  and  rationale   including  importance/relevance  of JHS  cohort  for the  problem       2 Data  requested  with  descriptive  information       3 Specification  of use  of genetic/DNA  information       4 Potential  stigmatization  issues  (cultural,  racial,  ethnic…)       5 Identification  of conflict  of interest       6 List  of co-authors  and  documentation  of their   responsibility.
